essay: Upon reading the news articles, a couple of thoughts came to mind. Firstly, it's astounding to see how much lower the statistics for car accident deaths have become. Secondly, I was intrigued to read that young suicides began to increase in 2007, which coincidentally was the year the iPhone was introduced. While I understand there are other contributing factors, it's hard to deny the negative impact of pervasive internet and social media. Additionally, when the lady mentioned that it's not normal for children to have suicidal thoughts, I couldn't help but laugh. Personally, I've been saying those same things for years-a sort of personal mantra. As someone who has often contemplated suicide as a solution or inevitability, it's intriguing to see others express similar thoughts.

essay: After reading the article, I found myself completely shocked and had to read it a second time to fully comprehend the gravity of the situation. The idea that young children are being exposed to opioid overdoses is absolutely disgusting. It's unfathomable how innocent and vulnerable toddlers are being put in harm's way by coming into contact with these dangerous substances. While some parents may accidentally drop these pills, it's still unacceptable that they would be so careless when it comes to the safety of their own child. This raises serious concerns about their ability to provide a secure environment for their children, causing a sense of disgust to rise inside me. Immediate action is needed, and one proposal could be to require a parenting evaluation as a prerequisite to having a child. It's unacceptable to continue subjecting children to such serious risks due to the reckless behavior of their caregivers.
